IPO.name: Initial Public Offering
IPO.definition: The process by which a private company offers shares to the public for the first time
IPO.example: When a company 'goes public', it conducts an IPO to raise capital from public investors

P/E Ratio.name: Price-to-Earnings Ratio
P/E Ratio.definition: A valuation metric that compares a company's stock price to its earnings per share
P/E Ratio.formula: P/E = Stock Price / Earnings Per Share
P/E Ratio.interpretation: Higher P/E may indicate overvaluation or high growth expectations. Lower P/E may indicate undervaluation or low growth. Industry average comparison is crucial.

EPS.name: Earnings Per Share
EPS.definition: A company's net profit divided by the number of outstanding shares
EPS.importance: Key indicator of company profitability on a per-share basis. Used in P/E ratio calculation.

Market Cap.name: Market Capitalization
Market Cap.definition: Total market value of a company's outstanding shares
Market Cap.formula: Market Cap = Share Price × Outstanding Shares

investment_characteristics.Large Cap: Lower risk, stable growth, often pay dividends
investment_characteristics.Small Cap: Higher risk, higher growth potential, volatile

ROE.name: Return on Equity
ROE.definition: Measure of profitability that shows how much profit a company generates with shareholders' equity
ROE.interpretation: Higher ROE indicates better efficiency in generating returns. Above 15% is generally considered good.

Dividend Yield.name: Dividend Yield
Dividend Yield.definition: Annual dividend payment as a percentage of stock price
Dividend Yield.formula: Dividend Yield = Annual Dividend per Share / Stock Price × 100%
Dividend Yield.interpretation: Higher yield may indicate good income investment, but verify sustainability. Very high yields (>8%) can signal distress.

Beta.name: Beta Coefficient
Beta.definition: Measure of a stock's volatility compared to the overall market (S&P 500)

interpretation.< 0: Inverse correlation to market (rare, e.g., gold stocks)

EBITDA.name: Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization
EBITDA.definition: Measure of company's operating performance before accounting and financing decisions
EBITDA.formula: EBITDA = Revenue - Operating Expenses (excluding interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization)
EBITDA.use_case: Compare profitability between companies and industries, especially capital-intensive ones

RSI.name: Relative Strength Index
RSI.definition: Momentum indicator measuring speed and magnitude of price changes

interpretation.> 70: Overbought - potential sell signal or take profit
interpretation.Divergence: Price makes new high but RSI doesn't = bearish. Price makes new low but RSI doesn't = bullish

RSI.period: Typically 14 days (can be adjusted for different timeframes)
RSI.best_use: Range-bound markets. Less reliable in strong trending markets.

MACD.name: Moving Average Convergence Divergence
MACD.definition: Trend-following momentum indicator showing relationship between two moving averages

components.Histogram: MACD line - Signal line (shows distance between lines)

signals.Bullish Crossover: MACD crosses above signal line (buy signal)
signals.Bearish Crossover: MACD crosses below signal line (sell signal)
signals.Divergence: Price makes new high/low but MACD doesn't (reversal warning)

MACD.best_use: Trending markets. Combine with support/resistance for confirmation.

Free Cash Flow.name: Free Cash Flow (FCF)
Free Cash Flow.definition: Cash generated after capital expenditures, available for distribution to investors
Free Cash Flow.formula: FCF = Operating Cash Flow - Capital Expenditures
Free Cash Flow.importance: Most accurate measure of company's financial health. Used in DCF valuation.

interpretation.Positive & Growing: Strong financial health, can pay dividends, reduce debt, invest
interpretation.Negative: May indicate growth phase (CapEx heavy) or financial stress

PEG Ratio.name: Price/Earnings to Growth Ratio
PEG Ratio.definition: P/E ratio adjusted for earnings growth rate
PEG Ratio.formula: PEG = P/E Ratio / EPS Growth Rate

interpretation.< 1: Potentially undervalued (stock is cheap relative to growth)

PEG Ratio.best_use: Comparing growth stocks. More reliable than P/E alone for high-growth companies.

S&P 500.name: Standard & Poor's 500
S&P 500.description: Stock market index tracking 500 largest U.S. publicly traded companies by market cap
S&P 500.weight_method: Market-cap weighted (largest companies have most influence)
S&P 500.characteristics: Most watched U.S. equity index. Considered benchmark for U.S. stock market and economy.

NASDAQ.name: NASDAQ Composite
NASDAQ.description: Index of all stocks listed on NASDAQ exchange, heavily weighted towards technology
NASDAQ.characteristics: Tech-heavy, growth-oriented, more volatile than S&P 500
NASDAQ.best_for: Investors seeking growth and tech exposure. Higher risk/reward than S&P 500.

Dow Jones.name: Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA)
Dow Jones.description: Price-weighted index of 30 prominent U.S. companies
Dow Jones.weight_method: Price-weighted (higher-priced stocks have more influence, regardless of market cap)
Dow Jones.history: Oldest U.S. market index (since 1896). Originally tracked industrial companies.
Dow Jones.characteristics: Blue-chip stocks, less tech-focused than NASDAQ, more stable than NASDAQ
Dow Jones.criticism: Only 30 stocks, price-weighting is outdated methodology

Russell 2000.name: Russell 2000 Index
Russell 2000.description: Small-cap stock market index of 2000 smallest U.S. companies
Russell 2000.characteristics: Small-cap indicator, more volatile, domestic-focused (less international exposure)
Russell 2000.best_for: Gauging small-cap performance and U.S. economic health. Higher growth potential but higher risk.

VIX.name: Volatility Index (CBOE)
VIX.description: Measure of market's expectation of 30-day volatility based on S&P 500 options
VIX.trading: Can trade VIX futures and options (VXX, UVXY ETFs)
VIX.use_case: Hedge against market downturns, gauge market sentiment

Value Investing.description: Strategy of selecting stocks trading below their intrinsic value
Value Investing.approach: Buy undervalued stocks with strong fundamentals and hold long-term (years)
Value Investing.best_for: Patient investors seeking margin of safety and steady returns
Value Investing.sectors: Often found in Financials, Utilities, Consumer Staples, Energy

Growth Investing.description: Investing in companies expected to grow at above-average rate
Growth Investing.characteristics: Higher P/E ratios, reinvest earnings (low/no dividends), focus on future potential
Growth Investing.best_for: Investors willing to accept volatility for higher long-term returns

Dividend Investing.description: Focus on stocks that pay regular, sustainable, and growing dividends
Dividend Investing.target_companies: Mature, profitable companies with stable cash flows (Dividend Aristocrats)

Momentum Trading.description: Strategy based on continuing trends in stock prices ('the trend is your friend')
Momentum Trading.timeframe: Short to medium term (days to months)
Momentum Trading.approach: Buy stocks showing upward momentum, sell when momentum fades
Momentum Trading.best_for: Active traders comfortable with technical analysis

Index Investing (Passive).description: Invest in index funds (ETFs or mutual funds) that track market indices
Index Investing (Passive).approach: Buy and hold, regular contributions (dollar-cost averaging)
Index Investing (Passive).best_for: Long-term investors (10+ years), beginners, hands-off approach
Index Investing (Passive).supporting_research: Beats 80-90% of active managers over 15+ years

Diversification.principle: Don't put all eggs in one basket - reduce unsystematic risk
strategies: Spread across 15-30 individual stocks (or use index funds)
Mix sectors (Tech, Healthcare, Finance, Consumer, Energy, etc.)
Asset class diversification (Stocks + Bonds + Real Estate + Commodities)
Market cap diversification (Large + Mid + Small cap)
Diversification.benefits: Reduces portfolio volatility and risk of catastrophic loss

Position Sizing.guideline: Limit single position to 5-10% of portfolio (3-5% for speculative)
Position Sizing.rationale: Minimize impact of individual stock failures while allowing winners to compound
Position Sizing.formula: Position Size = (Portfolio Value × Risk %) / (Entry Price - Stop Loss Price)
Position Sizing.example: $100k portfolio, 2% risk, $50 entry, $45 stop = $4k position (80 shares)

Stop Loss.definition: Predetermined price level to automatically exit losing position
Stop Loss.purpose: Limit downside risk, remove emotion from selling decision
Stop Loss.caution: Can be triggered by short-term volatility. Use wider stops for volatile stocks.

Risk/Reward Ratio.definition: Ratio of potential profit to potential loss
Risk/Reward Ratio.formula: R/R = (Target Price - Entry Price) / (Entry Price - Stop Loss)
Risk/Reward Ratio.guideline: Minimum 2:1 (risk $1 to potentially make $2). Professional traders often use 3:1.
Risk/Reward Ratio.example: Entry $50, Target $56, Stop $48 → R/R = 6/2 = 3:1 (good trade setup)

Portfolio Rebalancing.frequency: Quarterly or annually (or when allocation drifts >5% from target)
Portfolio Rebalancing.purpose: Maintain target asset allocation, take profits from winners, buy dips in laggards
Portfolio Rebalancing.method: Sell overweight positions, buy underweight positions to restore targets
Portfolio Rebalancing.tax_consideration: Use new contributions to rebalance in taxable accounts to avoid capital gains

trading_terminology.Bull Market: Sustained uptrend in prices (typically 20%+ gain from lows). Characterized by optimism and economic expansion.
trading_terminology.Bear Market: Sustained downtrend in prices (typically 20%+ decline from highs). Characterized by pessimism and economic contraction.
trading_terminology.Correction: Short-term decline of 10-20% from recent highs. Normal part of bull markets.
trading_terminology.Market Order: Order to buy/sell immediately at current market price. Guarantees execution but not price.
trading_terminology.Limit Order: Order to buy/sell at specified price or better. Guarantees price but not execution.
trading_terminology.Stop-Loss Order: Order that becomes market order when stock hits specified price. Used to limit losses.
trading_terminology.Bid-Ask Spread: Difference between highest buy price (bid) and lowest sell price (ask). Narrower = more liquid.
trading_terminology.Volume: Number of shares traded. High volume confirms price moves. Low volume = less conviction.
trading_terminology.Market Cap: Total value of company (Share Price × Shares Outstanding). Determines size classification.
trading_terminology.Float: Number of shares available for public trading (excludes insider holdings). Low float = more volatile.
trading_terminology.Short Selling: Borrowing shares to sell, hoping to buy back cheaper. Profits from price declines. Unlimited risk.
trading_terminology.Margin: Borrowing money from broker to buy stocks. Amplifies gains AND losses. Margin call = forced selling.
trading_terminology.Options: Contracts giving right (not obligation) to buy (call) or sell (put) at specified price. Used for hedging or speculation.
trading_terminology.Earnings Season: Period when public companies report quarterly results (Jan, Apr, Jul, Oct). High volatility.
trading_terminology.Ex-Dividend Date: Date you must own stock to receive dividend. Stock typically drops by dividend amount.
trading_terminology.Stock Split: Increases shares outstanding, lowers price (e.g., 2-for-1). No change in total value.
trading_terminology.Reverse Split: Decreases shares, increases price. Often bearish signal (trying to avoid delisting).

faq.question: What is the best time to invest in an IPO?
faq.answer:
Most experts suggest waiting 3-6 months after IPO for several reasons:

1. **Lockup Expiration** (typically 180 days): Insiders can sell, often causing price drops
2. **Price Stabilization**: Initial hype fades, price finds fair value
3. **More Data**: 1-2 quarterly earnings reports provide better insight
4. **Lower Volatility**: Post-lockup period usually less volatile

**Exception:** If you have high conviction based on fundamentals and the IPO prices reasonably (not at high end of range), buying on day 1 can work for long-term holds.

**Best Practice:** Research thoroughly, don't chase hype, use limit orders (IPOs can spike/crash), only invest what you can afford to lose.

faq.question: How do I evaluate if a stock is overvalued or undervalued?
faq.answer:
Use multiple methods for comprehensive valuation:

**1. Relative Valuation (Comparables)**
• P/E ratio vs industry average (lower = potentially undervalued)
• PEG ratio < 1 (undervalued), > 2 (overvalued)
• Price-to-Book < 1 (undervalued for asset-heavy businesses)
• EV/EBITDA vs peers

**2. Absolute Valuation**
• DCF (Discounted Cash Flow) analysis - complex but most accurate
• Compare current price to DCF-derived intrinsic value

**3. Growth Considerations**
• High P/E can be justified if growth is high (check PEG)
• Compare revenue/earnings growth to valuation multiples

**4. Qualitative Factors**
• Competitive advantages (moat)
• Management quality and capital allocation
• Industry trends and tailwinds
• Regulatory environment

**Red Flags:**
• P/E >30 with slowing growth
• Declining margins despite revenue growth
• High debt + low cash flow
• Negative FCF for mature companies

**Remember:** Price ≠ Value. A $500 stock can be cheap, a $10 stock can be expensive.

faq.question: What's the difference between market cap and enterprise value?
faq.answer:
**Market Cap = Share Price × Shares Outstanding**
• Represents equity value only
• What you'd pay to buy all shares
• Ignores debt and cash

**Enterprise Value (EV) = Market Cap + Debt - Cash**
• Represents total company value (equity + debt)
• What you'd pay to acquire the entire business
• More accurate for comparing companies

**Why EV Matters:**

1. **Debt Consideration:** Company A and B both have $10B market cap, but A has $5B debt and B has $0 debt. B is cheaper (lower EV).

2. **Cash Consideration:** Company C has $10B market cap and $3B cash. True EV is only $7B (you get $3B cash with purchase).

3. **Better for Comparisons:** EV/EBITDA is better than P/E for comparing companies with different capital structures.

**When to Use:**
• **Market Cap:** Simple comparisons, size classification, index weighting
• **Enterprise Value:** M&A analysis, valuation across industries, comparing companies with different leverage

faq.question: Should I invest in dividend stocks or growth stocks?
faq.answer:
Depends on your **goals, age, risk tolerance, and tax situation:**

**DIVIDEND STOCKS**

**Pros:**
• Regular income stream (3-6% yields typical)
• Lower volatility (defensive)
• Tax-advantaged (qualified dividends taxed at 0-20%)
• Compounding through DRIP (dividend reinvestment)
• Better in bear markets/recessions

**Cons:**
• Lower growth potential
• Can underperform in bull markets
• Dividend cuts during crises
• Less tax-efficient in taxable accounts

**Best For:** Retirees, income-focused investors, conservative portfolios, high tax brackets (vs bonds)

**Examples:** JNJ, KO, PG, VZ, T

---

**GROWTH STOCKS**

**Pros:**
• Higher potential returns (20%+ annually possible)
• Benefit from compounding (no dividend tax drag)
• Ride long-term secular trends (tech, innovation)
• Tax-efficient (control when to realize gains)

**Cons:**
• Higher volatility (50% drawdowns possible)
• No income stream
• More risk of permanent loss
• Harder to value (future growth uncertain)

**Best For:** Young investors (long time horizon), growth-focused portfolios, high risk tolerance

**Examples:** NVDA, TSLA, AMZN, META, GOOGL

---

**BALANCED APPROACH (Recommended for Most):**
• **Under 40:** 80% growth, 20% dividend
• **40-55:** 60% growth, 40% dividend
• **55-65:** 40% growth, 60% dividend
• **Retired:** 20% growth, 80% dividend/bonds

**Or:** Use index funds (VOO, VTI) that include both (~1.5% yield + 7% growth = 8.5% total return historically)

faq.question: How much of my portfolio should be in IPOs?
faq.answer:
**Conservative Recommendation: 5-10% maximum**

Here's why:

**HIGH RISK FACTORS:**
1. **Volatility:** 50-80% swings in first year common
2. **Limited Data:** No long-term track record
3. **Lockup Expirations:** Insider selling at 180 days causes drops
4. **Hype Premium:** Often overpriced at IPO (investors overpay)
5. **Failure Rate:** ~60% of IPOs trade below offer price after 3 years

**ALLOCATION FRAMEWORK:**

**Conservative Investor (Low Risk Tolerance):**
• **0-3% in IPOs**
• Focus: Profitable companies, proven business models
• Examples: Established tech (when they IPO), consumer brands

**Moderate Investor (Medium Risk Tolerance):**
• **5-8% in IPOs**
• Mix: Some growth stories, some profitable IPOs
• Diversify across 3-5 IPOs (don't concentrate)

**Aggressive Investor (High Risk Tolerance, Young):**
• **10-15% in IPOs**
• Focus: High-growth potential, disruptive companies
• Accept higher volatility for potential outsized returns

**BEST PRACTICES:**
1. **Never chase day-1 hype** - wait for lockup, earnings data
2. **Diversify across sectors** - don't put all in one industry
3. **Only invest what you can afford to lose** - IPOs can go to zero
4. **Research deeply** - read S-1 filing, understand business model
5. **Have an exit plan** - know when to cut losses or take profits

**Historical Context:**
• Best-performing IPOs (GOOGL, AMZN, NFLX) = life-changing returns
• Worst-performing (WeWork, Theranos) = total losses
• **Average:** Slightly underperforms market in first 3 years

**Conclusion:** IPOs should be a **small, speculative portion** of a diversified portfolio, not the core.

faq.question: What's a good Sharpe Ratio?
faq.answer:
**Sharpe Ratio** measures risk-adjusted returns: (Return - Risk-Free Rate) / Standard Deviation

**Interpretation:**
• **< 0:** Losing money (worse than risk-free rate)
• **0-1:** Subpar (not enough return for the risk taken)
• **1-2:** Good (acceptable risk-adjusted returns)
• **2-3:** Very Good (strong risk-adjusted performance)
• **> 3:** Excellent (exceptional risk-adjusted returns, rare)

**Context:**
• S&P 500 long-term: ~0.4-0.5 (decent)
• Top hedge funds: 1.0-1.5
• Warren Buffett (lifetime): ~0.8
• High-frequency trading firms: 2.0+

**Limitations:**
• Assumes normal distribution (fails for fat-tail events)
• Penalizes upside volatility same as downside
• Historical metric (past ≠ future)

**Better Alternative for Investors: Sortino Ratio** (only penalizes downside volatility)
